Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating the Role of Glaciation on the Structural Configuration of the Southern Alaska Syntaxis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The role of glaciation on the tectonic configuration of convergent margins is a first order question that remains largely unanswered. The eastern Gulf of Alaska is arguably the best place on Earth to study the coupling of glacial erosional processes and tectonics. The coastal mountains in this area, the Chugach and St. Elias Ranges, contain the largest non-polar ice fields on earth and are characterized by the most erosive agents on earth, tidewater glaciers, and are part of a wide zone of deformation that forms along the southern Alaska syntaxis. This structural, depositional, and climatic framework of the Gulf of Alaska provide the ideal study area to understand the relationship between glaciation and tectonics. Few places on earth have the extreme exhumation, erosional, and depositional rates that have been documented as in the syntaxial corner. Many recent studies provide evidence for intensified rock uplift in response to focused erosion by glaciers but the structural mechanics that are responsible for the reorganization of the mountain belt are not well understood in Alaska or elsewhere. This project has two basic goals: 1) to refine the structural cross-sections of the region using geologic data and, 2) develop mechanical analog models that account for the role of glacially driven erosion and deposition (amount and location) on the reorganization of deformation along the geologically and geometrically complex plate boundary of the Alaskan margin. Analog modeling will utilize state-of-the-art kinematic analysis to understand the development and evolution of structures.

The influence of glaciers in Southern Alaska, and in general, on tectonics is directly related to variations in climate, however, most models for the mechanical development of convergent margins are disconnected from the role of glaciations in mass redistribution and the coupled tectonic response. This modeling study will help to quantify the general mechanical response of Coulomb wedges to highly localized glacial erosion, which occurs on geologically rapid time scales, and more specifically will put constraints on the style and evolution of deformation along the Alaskan convergent margin. This work will help to elucidate both short and long-term response of mountain belts, including changes in uplift and strain patterns, due to rapid loading and unloading, that can occur during periods of rapid climate change. The project has a significant outreach and education component that seeks to increase diversity in the geosciences by working with high school Native American students from rural Alaskan communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mechanical evolution of convergent margins in response to focused glaciation is a first order question that impacts both our long and short term understanding of convergent margin development.  The feedback between glaciation and tectonics in convergent margins is relevant to understanding long-term exhumation of deep rocks due to variations in climate and, also our understanding of shorter-term seismic hazards in response to rapid changes in the balance of forces in a mountain belt. The eastern Gulf of Alaska is arguably the best place on earth to study the coupling of such glacial erosional processes and tectonics. The coastal mountains in this area, the Chugach and St. Elias Ranges, contain the largest non-polar ice fields on earth and are characterized by the most erosive agents on earth, tidewater glaciers. The Chugach and St. Elias Mountains are part of a wide zone of deformation that forms along the southern Alaska syntaxis.

In this study, we synthesized existing field observations from Alaska to constrain and inform the design of mechanical analog models for the development of brittle wedges in response to focused glacial erosion. We used field data to refine our understanding of cross-sections along the southern Alaska syntaxis. These new cross-sections and maps helped constrain our analog models. We developed scaled physical models to test and quantify the general mechanical response of brittle coulomb wedges to highly localized glacial erosion (such as is occurring in Alaska) that occurs on geologically rapid time scales. Using our models, we characterized the mechanical response of brittle mountain belts, and the geometry of the Chugach and St. Elias in particular, to the rapid removal of material from its surface.  We found that the impact strike-parallel erosion was accommodated rapidly by an intensified duration of accretion, rather than internal deformation, at the deformation front.  Such accretion had the impact of causing rapid under-thrusting of the foreland material and uplift in the hinterland of the model mountain belt. In conjunction with the removal of material this allowed for the rapid exhumation (bring to the surface) of deeper material.  Using image analysis we determined the change in rate and the cumulative effect that erosion had on the path that material took through our model mountain belt.  Furthermore, we identifed the exact structures that were responsible for the deformation in the wedge that allowed for the exhumation of material. This allowed us to evaluate the validity of controversial models for uplift in Alaska.

An important component of this proposal was education, outreach, and increasing diversity in the geosciences. The education and diversity component of the proposed research involved working with high school Native American students at New Mexico State University (NMSU) and underrepresented undergraduate students from University of Texas- El Paso (UTEP). NMSU has one of the highest enrollments of Native American students in the US and has been an important recruiting location for graduate students in STEM disciplines at Purdue. UTEP has a predominantly Hispanic student population and a significant African American student population primarily associated with the large military complex at Fort Bliss.

 

The field trip was named Geology of Rifts from Indigenous Perspectives (GRIP) and was run on November 5th, 2016. The trip introduced underrepresented students to the tectonics of the Rio Grande Rift system and the depositional environments of the Rio Grande River. Many of these students were from Native and Mexican American communities that are concentrated along the rift system but most do not understand the links between their communities and the geologic processes of the rift system. This program consisted of a field trip to several different geologic locations near Las Cruces, NM. The field sites were chosen to illustrate important rift geology concepts. This project also contributed to the education of three undergraduate research assistants and a significant part of a masters and Ph.D. for two graduate students, Kim Davis and Patrick Newman respectively.
